sub_title: Researcher on circularity in the built environment
summary: Joana dos Santos Gonçalves is a researcher on circularity in the built environment at VITO (Belgium). She graduated as an architect from the School of Architecture of University of Minho (Portugal) in 2014, with a master thesis on the contributions of vernacular architecture for sustainability. Joana was awarded with the Iberian Prize on Traditional Architecture Research in 2014 for her research in her master thesis. In 2016 she started her PhD on “Beyond good intentions: building passport for sustainable conservation”, funded by FCT, within the research program “EcoCoRe – Eco-Construction and Rehabilitation”, an International Doctoral Program on Sustainable Built Environment based in Portugal. Between 2019 and 2021 Joana was a guest PhD in the UNESCO chair on Heritage and the Reshaping of Urban Conservation for Sustainability, at TU Delft, the Netherlands. Her scientific contributions are disseminated in international journals and conferences (in Portugal, Spain, France, Belgium, and the Netherlands). Between 2020 and 2022, she was a lecturer on Heritage and Sustainability in the Architectural Engineering and Technology department, in the Faculty of Architecture and the Built Environment, at TU Delft, guiding master graduation projects on topics such as social engagement or zero waste approaches on heritage conservation. Joana is a regular reviewer for the journals Heritage, Sustainability, and Sustainable Cities and Society. She is a member of ICOMOS (Portugal) and INTBAU (Iberia).
